bibl.title: Letter from George P. Berry to Marion E. Gridley, March 3, 1953

div1.p: Berry answers Gridley's questions concerning the annual meetings and membership in the Walter Reed Society.

div1.head: Letter from George P. Berry to Marion E. Gridley, March 3, 1953
div1.opener:
COPY
HARVARD MEDICAL SCHOOL
OFFICE OF THE DEAN
25 SHATTUCK STREET
BOSTON, MASSACHUSETTS
March 3, 1953
Miss Marion E. Gridley
Secretary to the Awards Committee
The Walter Reed Society
208 North Wells Street
Chicago 6, Illinois
Dear Miss Gridley:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of February 23, 1953, to the members of the Awards
Committee of the Walter Reed Society. I am happy to know that Dr. Davison
and Dr. Reifenstein have been added to the Committee. I shall answer your
questions seriatim.

list.item:
1. To my great regret, conflicting engagements will prevent me from
being in Chicago on April 9th, thus making it impossible for me to attend
the annual meeting of the Walter Reed Society.

2.
a) and
b) I approve of the selection of Dr. Lloyd T. Koritz. It
seems to me excellent.
c) I have no other names to suggest.
d) I can not accept the Chairmanship owing to the pressure of other
commitments. I shall keep your problem in mind and do what I can to help you
secure one.
e) In seeking candidates for next year, it seems to me that the
Committee has a fine opportunity to continue to explain what the Walter Reed
Society is and what it stands for. My suggestion would be, therefore, to
begin any solicitation for nominations with an explanatory statement. Unless
a great number of nominations flow in, I should think that the Committee
could feel its way without trying to establish standards ahead of time.
f) At the annual meeting it seems to me that someone who is doing
important work that is possible only through the use of human volunteers
might be asked to speak. In selecting him, great weight should be put on the
public-relations aspects of the program concerned, it seems to me. We want
the Walter Reed Society to appeal to the man in the street.
g) I have told the members of our Faculty about the Walter Reed
Society. I shall continue to seek members for you.

div1.p:
I see no reason why posthumous awards are not in order. The two proposed
strike me as excellent suggestions. The more so in that the Cuban Government
has within recent months made Camp Lazear into a national park and given
much publicity to Carlos Finley's contribution to the solution of the yellow
fever problem. If you want to know more about this, write to Dr. Philip S.
Huench at the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minnesota. He was the “Sherlock Holmes”
who discovered Camp Lazear and the moving spirit in winning Cuban recognition.
Naturally, all of this has great value in the field of international relations.
It would be an excellent move for the Walter Reed Society too, for yellow
fever is a matter that the public has heard a good deal about.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George Packer Berry, M.D.
Dean GPB/h
cc: Dr. Huench
